Causal Inference Methods Overview

causal-methods-overview.Rmd

üß† What is Causal Inference?

Causal inference is the process of estimating the effect of an intervention or treatment on an outcome. Unlike correlation, causal inference requires assumptions about how data was generated.

In this article, we use the fund_performance dataset to illustrate common methods.

data("fund_performance")
head(fund_performance)
##   fund_id market_return        alpha      beta treatment       return
## 1       1   0.003952435 -0.009915974 0.9217857         0 -0.007775751
## 2       2   0.036982251 -0.010799101 1.1331275         1  0.032828934
## 3       3   0.215870831  0.009640395 1.0374590         1  0.224115880
## 4       4   0.067050839  0.007356497 1.1228787         1  0.080673608
## 5       5   0.072928774 -0.040986855 0.9176203         0  0.051918971
## 6       6   0.231506499  0.030811469 0.8564341         0  0.228707376

‚öñÔ∏è 1. Naive Difference in Means

This method assumes random treatment assignment.

fund_performance %>%
  group_by(treatment) %>%
  summarise(mean_return = mean(return))
## # A tibble: 2 √ó 2
##   treatment mean_return
##       <int>       <dbl>
## 1         0      0.0724
## 2         1      0.0764

üéØ 2. Propensity Score Matching (PSM)

PSM attempts to create a balanced dataset by matching treated and control units on their probability of receiving treatment.

psm <- matchit(treatment ~ market_return + alpha + beta, data = fund_performance, method = "nearest")
summary(psm)
## 
## Call:
## matchit(formula = treatment ~ market_return + alpha + beta, data = fund_performance, 
##     method = "nearest")
## 
## Summary of Balance for All Data:
##               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
## distance             0.4942        0.4919          0.0961     0.9914    0.0250
## market_return        0.0623        0.0610          0.0134     0.9360    0.0079
## alpha                0.0102        0.0115         -0.0687     0.9442    0.0194
## beta                 0.9919        0.9993         -0.0654     0.9965    0.0186
##               eCDF Max
## distance        0.0725
## market_return   0.0232
## alpha           0.0512
## beta            0.0413
## 
## Summary of Balance for Matched Data:
##               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
## distance             0.4942        0.4920          0.0887     1.0413    0.0230
## market_return        0.0623        0.0602          0.0208     0.9314    0.0088
## alpha                0.0102        0.0113         -0.0568     0.9830    0.0167
## beta                 0.9919        0.9992         -0.0650     1.0060    0.0185
##               eCDF Max Std. Pair Dist.
## distance        0.0730          0.0927
## market_return   0.0243          1.1393
## alpha           0.0467          0.8110
## beta            0.0426          0.8197
## 
## Sample Sizes:
##           Control Treated
## All           507     493
## Matched       493     493
## Unmatched      14       0
## Discarded       0       0

Check matched data:

matched_data <- match.data(psm)
ggplot(matched_data, aes(x = return, fill = factor(treatment)))

  geom_density(alpha = 0.5)
## geom_density: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, outline.type = upper
## stat_density: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA

üå≤ 3. Causal Forests (Optional)

You can also use more advanced estimators like causal forests (via the grf package). These are not covered here but can estimate heterogeneous treatment effects.

Install and explore here: https://grf-labs.github.io/grf/

üìå Summary

Method When to Use
Naive Difference-in-Means Randomized experiments
Propensity Score Matching Observational studies with covariate overlap
Causal Forests Heterogeneous treatment effects
